awd_titl_txt: A Study of Knowledge Flow and Recurring Costly Infrastructure Failures
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for Early Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER). It is a case study of structural engineering failures due to faulty design decisions. The PI will engage in archival research and interviews of experts in the field (and related fields including architecture) to bring to light the culture and traditions of structural engineering practice concerning the use of knowledge in design decision making. Specifically, she will focus on occurrences of inadvertent neglect of pertinent available knowledge in design decision-making that unintentionally caused failures, in some cases soon after the structures were placed into service. The PI has nine case studies planned. This grant will support research for the first of the nine planned studies, which concerns the use of galvanized high-strength steel. The PI has done preliminary historical analysis and interviews to substantiate pursuing this case in much greater depth. The results from this project will provide the foundation for the PI's larger effort, serve to introduce the Science, Technology, and Society (STS) community to an overlooked engineering profession, and bring to light decades of recurring failures, many not well publicized that, that in some respects have broader, deeper adverse effects on society than one-time (singular) catastrophic events. 

This project is both innovative and potentially transformative. It will develop a hybrid conceptual framework that combines Actor Network Theory (an STS approach to socio-technical systems) with a Knowledge Management Systems approach that deals with knowledge facilitators (creators, carriers, conveyors, and users), impeders, and feedback loops within and among organizations. The PI will argue that neither of the two frameworks mentioned is adequate for capturing pertinent elements of her case study, which is best understood in terms of a framework that combines the most relevant features of both frameworks. In addition, the PI will prepare/present a peer-reviewed paper for an STS journal, a peer-reviewed paper for an engineering studies journal, a technical article for a professional structural engineering magazine, and a conference paper at the 2017 meeting of the Society for Social Studies of Science. The results of this project will be of interest to members of the public as well as structural engineers, architects, and historians of technology.

por.por_cntn:
NSF's Science and Technology Studies (STS) program funded a research project entitled "A Study of Knowledge Flow and Recurring Costly Infrastructure Failures" This program "supports research that uses historical, philosophical, and social scientific methods to investigate the intellectual, material, and social facets of the scientific, technological, engineering and mathematical (STEM) disciplines..." The grant was an Early-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) which "supports exploratory work in its early stages on untested, by potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This work could be considered especially 'high risk, high payoff' in the sense that is involved radically different approaches, applied new expertise engages novel disciplinary or interdisciplinary perspectives."

The background behind this research project is as follows:

Society relies upon engineers to design structures that offer reliable, predictable performance. To accomplish this, engineers make design decisions based upon deep-rooted, past experience that includes extensive laboratory testing programs. The acquired knowledge is formalized (i.e., codified) in consensus documents such as codes, standards, specifications, and design guidelines.

Yet, infrastructure fails taking lives, imposing financial burdens on taxpayers, and disrupting daily activities. Some causes of failure are obvious, such as a chronic lack of funding for inspection, maintenance, repair, and replacement, as well as the public's demand having grown to exceed the capacity of infrastructure. Also, evidence exists that design engineers make cognitive errors that surveys have shown to occur in approximately one-third of the failures. Cognitive errors may be of two types: (a) design engineers did not recognize well-established knowledge or (b) they recognized this knowledge and extrapolated from it. Extrapolation is essentially conjecture about future performance. If extrapolation is recognized, say for an "innovative" design, it should be accompanied by proper, quantified risk assessment.

After structural failures, forensic (structural) engineers are hired by attorneys to determine the technical cause(s) of failure. However, they are not hired to determine the "root" causes of failure, such as lack of use or non-use of existing knowledge. That is, the root cause of problems with knowledge flow and subsequent making of cognitive errors have received very little attention which is one reason why they keep recurring.

The focus of the EAGER grant was to determine how to outline research studies on knowledge flow and cognitive errors. The outline is called a "conceptual framework." A number of STS researchers use a well-known conceptual framework developed by a sociologist. This conceptual framework is centered around a (self-contained) network with relationships among people and things for which the duration is relatively short-lived and the geographic location is fixed. As such, it is too restrictive for a study that needs to include more than engineering practitioners. It need to include: knowledge flow (i.e., creators, carriers, conveyors, users, impeders (if any), and feedback loops (if created after failures)), organizations and entities outside of engineers' offices including the construction industry, a chronology of events that led up to and occurred after structural failures, and reactions and responses to structural failures. These must become part of a conceptual framework that will guide the actual research project toward an explanation(s) of the recurrence of failure events.

Using several structural failures as "pilot" studies, the PI found that it is possible to develop a conceptual framework for each study that can be effectively communicated with audiences of STS researchers and engineers. To accomplish this, the PI presented seminars and webinars, and published several articles and papers and solicited questions, comments, and feedback. Responses indicated that the audiences understood the new conceptual framework and its merit for use in engineering studies.

The conceptual framework stems from STS but is hybrid because it draws upon other fields in which rely on conceptual frameworks to represent knowledge flow. Thus, it is called "an STS hybrid conceptual framework." With this special conceptual framework, the PI has an appropriate tool to outline and then carry out future studies of engineers, engineering knowledge, and recurring failures of engineered artifacts. It can be applied to a failure type that has been occurring for many years across related engineering fields.

This project is transformative, because it introduced the STS community to the following: (1) an overlooked engineering profession, (2) decades of recurring failures that, in some respects, have broader, deeper adverse affects on society than one-time (singular) catastrophic events, and, most importantly, (3) a new STS hybrid conceptual framework.

The results from this project will provide the foundation for the PI's larger effort which will also be transformative. The results will offer the following: (1) recommendations to improve structural engineering education (i.e., importance of materials science engineering courses which are required for engineering students in related fields), structural engineering practice, licensure, and continuing education, and (2) recommendations for more forward-thinking public policy regarding infrastructure by improving how structural design decisions are made. These will lead to broader, deeper sociotechnical understanding of design engineers.
